/* Legislation */
revision.text:
{{CdnCrimOffences|Forceable Entry}} ==Legislation== {{quotation| '''Forcible entry'''
72. (1) A person commits forcible entry when that person enters real property that is in the actual and peaceable possession of another in a manner that is likely to cause a breach of the peace or reasonable apprehension of a breach of the peace.
'''Matters not material'''
(1.1) For the purposes of subsection (1), it is immaterial whether or not a person is entitled to enter the real property or whether or not that person has any intention of taking possession of the real property.
'''Forcible detainer'''
(2) A person commits forcible detainer when, being in actual possession of real property without colour of right, he detains it in a manner that is likely to cause a breach of the peace or reasonable apprehension of a breach of the peace, against a person who is entitled by law to possession of it.
'''Questions of law'''
(3) The questions whether a person is in actual and peaceable possession or is in actual possession without colour of right are questions of law.
R.S., 1985, c. C-46, s. 72; R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 10; 1992, c. 1, s. 60(F).
'''Punishment'''
73. Every person who commits forcible entry or forcible detainer is guilty of :(a) an offence punishable on summary conviction; or :(b) an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years.
R.S., 1985, c. C-46, s. 73; R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 11; 1992, c. 1, s. 58. |[http://www.canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec72 CCC] }} ==Application== ==Ancillary Orders== * s. 110 firearms prohibition (discretionary) ==Ranges== ==See Also== * [[Canadian Criminal Sentencing/Offences/Break and Enter]] {{OffencesNavBar/Property}} {{OffencesNavBar/Violence}} {{BookCat}} [[Category:Canadian Criminal Offences|Forceable Entry]]

72. (1) A person commits forcible entry when that person enters real property that is in the actual and peaceable possession of another in a manner that is likely to cause a breach of the peace or reasonable apprehension of a breach of the peace.
'''Matters not material'''
(1.1) For the purposes of subsection (1), it is immaterial whether or not a person is entitled to enter the real property or whether or not that person has any intention of taking possession of the real property.
'''Forcible detainer'''
(2) A person commits forcible detainer when, being in actual possession of real property without colour of right, he detains it in a manner that is likely to cause a breach of the peace or reasonable apprehension of a breach of the peace, against a person who is entitled by law to possession of it.
'''Questions of law'''
(3) The questions whether a person is in actual and peaceable possession or is in actual possession without colour of right are questions of law.
R.S., 1985, c. C-46, s. 72; R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 10; 1992, c. 1, s. 60(F).

'''Punishment'''
73. Every person who commits forcible entry or forcible detainer is guilty of :(a) an offence punishable on summary conviction; or :(b) an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years.
R.S., 1985, c. C-46, s. 73; R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 11; 1992, c. 1, s. 58. |[http://canlii.ca/t/7vf2#sec72 CCC] }} ==Interpretation== {{stub}} ==See Also== * [[Canadian Criminal Law/Offences/Break and Enter]] * [[Canadian Criminal Law/Offences/Unlawfully in a Dwelling]] {{OffencesNavBar/Property}} {{OffencesNavBar/Violence}} {{BookCat}} [[Category:Canadian Criminal Offences|Forceable Entry]]

revision.comment: Protected "[[Template:Convert/Mach]]": Uses complex features of wiki syntax (‎[edit=sysop] (indefinite) ‎[move=sysop] (indefinite))

revision.text:
{{Documentation subpage}} <!-- PLEASE ADD CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS PAGE --> <!-- --------------------------------------------------------------------- --NOTES: -- -- NOTE A1: This template converts Mach number of objects moving in -- the [[Atmosphere of Earth]] to other speed units, -- allowing the altitude in either parameter 3 or 4 to set the -- speed of sound by a #switch based on altitude divided by 5000 -- to select the speed of sound at increments of 5,000 feet. -- -- NOTE N3: The selection of parameter 3 or 4 is done by multiplying -- by 0 in #expr & compare to "0" by #ifeq to reject non-numeric -- data. So, if parameter 3 (or 4) is numeric, the value is used: -- #ifeq: {{#expr:( {{formatnum:{{{3|}}}|R}} )*0}}|0 -- |{{formatnum:{{{3}}}|R}} }} -- The {{formatnum:...|R}} removes any commas in the altitude. A -- lead zero ensures a numeric value, as in: 0{{{3|}}}{{{4}}}}, -- so if neither {3} nor {4} are numeric, the altitude is "0". -- Then the whole amount is divided by 5,000 feet (and rounded) -- to branch to the relative speed of sound at that altitude. -- --------------------------------------------------------------------- --HISTORY: --26Feb2012 Created to convert Mach number with other speed units. --26Feb2012 Allowed altitude in parameter 3 to avoid rounding in {4}. --26Feb2012 Put NOTES comments to explain template markup & operation. --26Feb2012 Put HISTORY comments to log major changes (not typos). -->
'''[[Template:Convert/Mach]]''' converts speeds of objects in [[w:Atmosphere of Earth|Earth's atmosphere]] in [[w:Mach number|Mach number]] with other units, where the optional parameter 3 (or 4) can be the altitude above (or below) [[w:mean sea level|mean sea level]], expressed in feet. Some examples are shown below. : '''Usage:''' {{convert|1|Mach}} → Mach 1 (761 mph; 1,225 km/h) :::   {{convert|2.0|Mach}} → {{convert|2.0|Mach}} :::   {{convert|3.3|Mach}} → {{convert|3.3|Mach}} :::   {{convert|3.3|Mach|90,000}} → {{convert|3.3|Mach|90,000}} :::   {{convert|3.3|Mach|90,000|sigfig=6}} → {{convert|3.3|Mach|90,000|sigfig=6}} :::   {{convert|810|mph|Mach}} → {{convert|810|mph|Mach}} :::   {{convert|810|mph|Mach|sigfig=4}} → {{convert|810|mph|Mach|sigfig=4}}
The conversion depends on the altitude, passed as parameter 3 or 4 measured in feet (default: 0), and the temperature (ignored), where the temperature at higher altitudes is likely to be fairly constant. Hence, only the altitude is an optional parameter, when converting from Mach number into other speed units. The altitude cannot be specified in reverse conversions, to Mach number, from other units, and the altitude is only accepted as feet, not meters.
Note that the [[w:speed of sound|speed of sound]] alternately decreases then increases, and again decreases then increases, at successively higher altitudes in the Earth's atmosphere. From [[w:sea level|sea level]], in the [[w:troposphere|troposphere]], the speed decreases with rising altitude until the [[w:tropopause|tropopause]], at {{convert|40,000|ft|mi km|0}}, where Mach 1 is {{convert|660.1|mph|km/h|1}}, for most commercial jet [[w:airliner|airliner]]s. However, the speed increases (as a reverse change) in the [[w:stratosphere|stratosphere]], reaching {{convert|737.7|mph|km/h|1}} at altitude {{convert|160,000|ft|mi km|0}}. Then, the speed re-reverses to again decrease in the [[w:mesosphere|mesosphere]], down to {{convert|613.2|mph|km/h |1|abbr=on}} at altitude {{convert|285,000|ft|mi km|0}}. However, in the [[w:thermosphere|thermosphere]], the speed of sound re-re-reverses to increase (as in the stratosphere), and reaches {{convert|688.9|mph|km/h|1|abbr=on}} at altitude {{convert|400,000|ft|mi km|0}}. The highest speeds are below sea level, as in low-lying canyon areas, and the template allows a lowest altitude of -15,000 (feet) in parameter 3 or 4. <includeonly> <!-- CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS HERE, THANKS --> [[Category:Subtemplates of Template Convert]] </includeonly>

revision.text:
{{Documentation subpage}} <!-- PLEASE ADD CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS PAGE -->
'''[[Template:Convert/SpellnumSrtLoff]]''' spells the numeric magnitude of parameter 1, as "thousand" for 3, "million" for 6, "billion" for 9, "trillion" for 12, etc. If the number in parameter 1 is not supported, the message "Invalid number" will be displayed instead. <includeonly> <!-- CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS HERE, THANKS --> [[Category:Subtemplates of Template Convert]] </includeonly>

revision.comment: Please be constructive
revision.text:
{{tmbox|type=notice|text='''Please help <u>''improve''</u> Wikibooks'''.
Your [[Special:Contributions/216.249.90.181|recent edits]] are considered unconstructive by fellow contributors. Please read [[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks?]] for a description of what we allow. You can ask questions or ask for help in the [[WB:HELP|Assistance Reading Room]]. Please use the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]] for experimenting with the wiki software in the future. Thanks. --[[User:Jomegat|Jomegat]] ([[User talk:Jomegat|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Jomegat|contribs]]) 01:19, 11 May 2012 (UTC)}}

revision.comment: added exclude in print cat and latex/top see also
revision.text:
{{Documentation subpage}} <!-- PLEASE ADD CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS PAGE -->
This template is the table of contents of the [[LaTeX]] wikibook. It is used on its main page and in the TOC box on each subpage.
=== Usage === * <nowiki>{{LaTeX/Contents}}</nowiki> will give the TOC naked with sub-numbering (for the print version) * <nowiki>{{LaTeX/Contents|subnum=false}}</nowiki> will give the TOC naked without sub-numbering (useful for boxes in subpages) * <nowiki>{{LaTeX/Contents|subnum=true|stage=true}}</nowiki> will give the TOC with sub-numbering and the stages icons (for the main page)
The default values of the arguments are * subnum: true * stage: false
=== See also === * [[LaTeX]] * [[Template:LaTeX/Top|LaTeX/Top template]]
<includeonly> <!-- CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS HERE, THANKS --> [[Category:Exclude in print|{{PAGENAME}}]]
</includeonly>

This template is made to be used at the top of each section-page of the [[{{ROOTBOOKNAME}}]] book. It is a collapsible table collapsed by default.

revision.comment: Protected "[[Template:Convert/x/AonSoffAnd]]": Uses complex features of wiki syntax (‎[edit=sysop] (indefinite) ‎[move=sysop] (indefinite))
revision.text: <!-- -============================================================= - Convert/x/AoffSoffAnd - Show two 2-unit amounts (ft&in,...) -============================================================= -- (see NOTES at bottom) --------------------- Show 1st whole amount -->{{#ifeq:{{{u|in}}}|in|<!-- then-->{{#ifeq:{{{2|12}}}|12|<!-- (see NOTE Z12) then-->{{#expr: {{{1|0}}} +1}}<!--show 1st whole feet+1 else-->|{{{1}}}<!--show 1st whole feet -->}}<!--endifeq {2}=12 else-->|{{{1}}}<!--show 1st whole amount (pounds, etc.) -->}}<!--endifeq {u}=in --> <!--show space --------------------- Show 1st whole-unit name -->{{#ifeq:{{{u|in}}}|in|<!-- then feet-->{{#ifexpr: {{{1|1}}}=1 and {{{2|1}}}<12 <!-- --> or {{{1|1}}}=0 and {{{2|1}}}=12 |<!-- then-->ft|<!--else-->ft}}<!-- else other unit-->|<!-- -->{{#ifeq:{{{1|1}}}|1|<!-- then-->{{{uu}}}|<!--else plural-->{{{uu}}}<!-- -->}}<!--endif {1}=1-- -->}}<!--endif {u}=in-- --> <!-- --------------------- Show 1st sub-unit (0 when 12 inches) -->{{#ifeq:{{{u|in}}}|in|<!-- then-->{{#ifeq:{{{2|12}}}|12|<!-- (see NOTE Z12) then-->0<!--else-->|{{{2}}}<!--show inches -->}}<!--endifeq {2}=12 -->}}<!--endifeq {u}=in --> <!--show space -->{{#ifexpr:{{{2|1}}} < 1.0001 and {{{2|1}}}>0 |<!-- then singular-->{{{u}}}|<!--else-->{{{u}}}}}<!-- ------------------------- --> {{{dualsep|×}}} <!--show separator (as: x, and, by) --------------------- Show 2nd whole amount -->{{#ifeq:{{{u|in}}}|in|<!-- then-->{{#ifeq:{{{4|12}}}|12|<!-- (see NOTE Z12) then-->{{#expr: {{{3|1}}} +1}}<!--show 2nd whole feet+1 else-->|{{{3}}}<!--show 2nd whole feet from param. 3 -->}}<!--endifeq {2}=12 else-->|{{{3}}}<!--show 2nd whole amount (param. 3) -->}}<!--endifeq {u}=in --> <!--show space --------------------- Show 2nd whole-unit name -->{{#ifeq:{{{u|in}}}|in|<!-- then feet-->{{#ifexpr: {{{3|2}}}=1 and {{{4|1}}}<12 <!-- --> or {{{3|2}}}=0 and {{{4|1}}}=12 |<!-- then-->ft|<!--else-->ft}}<!-- else other unit-->|<!-- -->{{#ifeq:{{{3|1}}}|1|<!-- then-->{{{uu}}}|<!--else plural-->{{{uu}}}<!-- -->}}<!--endif {3}=1-- -->}}<!--endif {u}=in-- --> <!-- --------------------- Show 2nd sub-unit -->{{#ifeq:{{{u|in}}}|in|<!-- then-->{{#ifeq:{{{4|12}}}|12|<!-- (see NOTE Z12) then-->0<!--else-->|{{{4}}}<!--show inches -->}}<!--endifeq {4}=12 -->}}<!--endifeq {u}=in --> <!--show space -->{{#ifexpr:{{{4|2}}} < 1.0001 and {{{4|2}}}>0 |<!-- then singular-->{{{u}}}|<!--else-->{{{u}}}}}<!-- ============================================================== --NOTES -- -- NOTE P3: This template uses the following parameters: -- {{{1}}} = 1st whole units (such as feet: 3) -- {{{2}}} = 1st sub-units (such as inches: 5) -- {{{3}}} = 2nd whole units (such as feet: 4) -- {{{4}}} = 2nd sub-units (such as inches: 6) -- {{{dualsep}}} = dual separator (such as: and, by, x) -- {{{u}}} = sub-unit symbol (such as: in) -- {{{n}}} = sub-unit name (such as: inch) -- {{{l}}} = sub-unit plural (such as: inches) -- There is no value passed as parameter 5 (empty). -- -- NOTE S4: This template shows the whole-unit names based on -- checking the sub-unit symbol (such as: in, oz) due to -- lacking parameters for whole-unit singular/plural. If -- whole-unit parameters were available, then they could -- be displayed (after amounts {1} & {3}) depending on -- whether each whole-unit amount was singular or plural -- (such as: foot, feet, pound, pounds). -- -- NOTE C5: Many HTML comments ("<!--") are used here to help -- indicate the end of nested if-expressions and describe -- step-by-step operation of this template. Extremely -- error-prone, a mismatched comment is a treacherous -- problem because they can go undetected until some -- particular option triggers the nearby logic branch -- which might then display the closing "...->". There -- should be an edit-tool to scan mismatched comments -- and report where an unclosed comment started. -- -- NOTE T6: For testing, the DEBUG-display can be triggered -- when parameter 2 {{{2}}} is 1.9, such as when using -- {{convert|1.876|x|3|m|ftin|abbr=none}}. The value -- as 1.876 (3 decimals) gives 1.9 inches, hence debug. -- -- NOTE Z12: In some conversions, the leftover inches have -- rounded to 12, so the logic here will adjust when -- sub-unit {u} is "in" to add 1 foot to 1st or 2nd -- feet when inches=12 then show 0 "in" which is -- the same plural as 12 inches. -- -- NOTE X9: For simplicity of development, the coding of -- this template is Template:Convert/x/AoffSoffAnd -- copied & names/plurals changed to {{{uu}}} {{{u}}}. -- Make major changes in that template, then re-copy -- here, changing {nn} & {ll} to {uu}, {n}&{l} to {u}. -- -------------------------------------------------------------- --HISTORY --15Nov09 Created to show two 2-unit amounts abbreviated. --15Nov09 Put NOTES comments to explain template coding. --15Nov09 Put HISTORY comments to log major changes. --15Nov09 Changed whole-unit symbol to use {uu}. -- --><noinclude> [[Category:Subtemplates of Template Convert]] </noinclude>

{{Documentation subpage}} <!-- PLEASE ADD CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS PAGE -->
'''[[Template:Convert/arpent]]''' converts arpent (Canada) to hectares, as 1 hectare = 2.92492592625 arpents. Source: Convertunits.com, 2010, webpage: [http://www.convertunits.com/from/hectare/to/arpent+%5BCanada%5D Cunits-arpent-Canada]. <includeonly> <!-- CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS HERE, THANKS --> [[Category:Subtemplates of Template Convert]] </includeonly>

revision.text:
{{Documentation subpage}} <!-- PLEASE ADD CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS PAGE -->
'''[[Template:Convert/by]]''' (for ranges using "by") is invoked as the first template below {Convert}, for converting ranges such as {Convert|2|by|4|ft|m}. It immediately invokes Convert/{4}, for the input unit {4}, passing the range of input numbers as "{1}|by|{3}". Having obtained all 8 parameters, {1}|by|{3}-{8}, it sets the precision "s" from either parameter {5}, {6} or {8} (depending on whichever is the numeric round-number); otherwise, the precision is set as: <nowiki>s=(0.5)+(0{{{s}}})</nowiki>. It passes {d} down as Dual/{d} to invoke subtemplate Convert/Dual/{d} which displays the dual-range (rather than a typical single amount). For any customization, such as disp=x, the parameters {6} and {7} are passed as {5} and {6} (or null if none). <includeonly> <!-- CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS HERE, THANKS --> [[Category:Subtemplates of Template Convert]] </includeonly>

revision.text:
Howdy y'all,
I'm mostly active on the German Wikipedia, so if it's urgent please visit my [[:de:w:Benutzer:Janneman|User/Discussion]] pages there.
My aim here is to create a more or less comprehensive [[The Short Stories of Nathaniel: An Annotated Secondary Bibliography|annotated bibliography of secondary literature relating to the short stories of Nathanael Hawthorne]]. This might take a while. Help is welcome. --[[User:Janneman|Janneman]] ([[User talk:Janneman|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Janneman|contribs]]) 17:18, 11 May 2012 (UTC)

revision.comment: /* Name several stargazers of the Bible. */
revision.text:
{{Adventist Adventurer Awards/Header|class=Builder}}
==Name several stargazers of the Bible.==
* Adam and Eve (Education, page 21) * Abraham (Genesis 15:5) * Joseph (Education, page 52) * Jesus (SDA Commentary, Volume 5, page 1117) * Moses (Patriarchs & Prophets, page 475) * Wise Men (Matthew 2:2)
==Identify one planet, two stars, and three constellations in the sky at night and give their correct names.== [[Image:Solar sys.jpg|thumb|220px]]
Go out at night to observe the sky and draw a picture of the planet, stars and the constellations you saw. When possible visit a planetarium.
==Make a constellation peep box.== Find the complete instructions at [http://www.middleschoolscience.com/shoeboxplanetarium.htm Shoe Box Planetarium Project]
'''Materials:'''
* shoe box * black construction paper * compass or sharp point * scissors * penny * ruler * star maps, books, or research links * permanent marker * tracing paper (optional) * white crayon, whiteout, or gel pen * index cards * tape
'''Procedure:'''
Research your constellation and write the following information neatly on a 3 x 5 index card in black ink (you may type the info if you choose).
* Name of Constellation * # of stars * Season best viewed * Name 3-4 constellations that border yours * Coordinates in degrees and hours * Brightest star(s) Name and Magnitude * Special features found in your constellations (ex. galaxies, nebulae, meteor showers, etc.....) * Inside of shoebox lid: * Write your name at the top of one end in permanent marker. * Underneath your name, place a picture of your constellation that shows the stars connected. * Place a picture of the mythological figure for your constellation. * Glue the index card with your information underneath those 2 pictures. * Place lid on box.
'''Shoe box bottom instructions:'''
* Place your name on the outside bottom of the shoebox using a permanent marker. * Using your ruler, find the center of one end of a shoebox. * Place a penny in the center and trace it. This will be your viewer. * Using a scissor, carefully bore out the cardboard so that the view hole is the size of the traced penny. * Place the lid on the shoebox. * On the opposite end, draw a line where the lid meets the side. Take lid off. * Using your ruler, mark 2 cm from the bottom, and 2 cm from each side. * Cut out the rectangle * Cut your black construction paper so that it will cover the rectangular opening. * Use tracing paper to copy your constellation and then place it on top of the black paper. Poke holes through the tracing paper and black paper. * Make larger holes for brighter stars and smaller holes for dimmer stars. * Place the black paper inside the box to cover the rectangular opening. Be sure that the constellation is facing you, not the outside of the box. * Tape paper to box.
'''Outside of Shoe Box'''
Have students bring in shoeboxes and let them spend a few minutes each day viewing the different boxes and guessing what constellation it is. To check, they can open the box and look inside the lid to see if they were right as well as check facts about their constellation.
==Explain the difference between a planet and a star.==
A star is a single body, such as the North Star. A constellation is a group of stars, such as the Big Dipper. Some of the brightest stars are Polaris, Castor, Regulus, Deneb, Altair, Rigel, Capella, and Vega. Orion, Leo, Libra, Lyra, Virgo, Taurus, Ursa Major, Ursa Minor, and Canis Major and Minor are a few of the constellations. Choose several of each, locating ones that are easiest to find and identify in your area during the time of year you are taking the class.
==Observe planets and stars in the night sky.==
==Observe two of the following and make a crayon resist:==
* moon rise * sunrise * sunset
'''Crayon Resist'''
Make a picture with wax crayons on a sturdy piece of paper. Leave some parts of the picture uncolored. Paint over the picture with tempera paints or water color. (Use black or dark blue for the night sky.) The paint will not stick to the crayoned part of the picture only to the blank paper, so the picture will stand out clearly against the painted background.
==Find three texts in the Bible that refer to the heavens.==
{{Bible verse|book=Genesis|chapter=1|verse=16|version=NIV|text=''God made two great lights—the greater light to govern the day and the lesser light to govern the night. He also made the stars..''}}
{{Bible verse|book=Deuteronomy|chapter=10|verse=22|version=NIV|text=''Your ancestors who went down into Egypt were seventy in all, and now the Lord your God has made you as numerous as the stars in the sky.''}}
{{Bible verse|book=Isaiah|chapter=13|verse=10|version=NIV|text=''The stars of heaven and their constellations will not show their light. The rising sun will be darkened and the moon will not give its light..''}}
== Internal Resources ==
[[Wikijunior:Solar_System|Solar System]] = Wikibook
==External Resources==
Adventurer Manual - [http://www.kfw-adventurers.org/awards/Hygiene.html KFW Adventurers]

revision.text: <noinclude><!-- -============================================================= - Convert/dimcode - Get dimension code for some units -============================================================= - (see NOTES at bottom) --></noinclude>{{ #switch: {{{1}}} | m | cm | mm | dm | km | mi | chain | yd | ft | in | link | ch | league | micron | parsec | AU = L | m2 | cm2 | mm2 | km2 | sqmi | sqyd | sqft | sqin = A | m3 | cm3 | mm3 | km3 | cumi | cuyd | cuft | cuin = V | g | kg | lb | oz | ST | LT | ton | tonnes = M | L | l | litres | mL | ml | USgal | qt | pint | cu | floz = FV | #default = none }}<noinclude><!--endswitch {o}--><!-- -------------------------------------------------------------- --NOTES: -- -- NOTE A1: This template acts as an [[accessor function]] and -- returns the dimension-code for some units, to avoid -- trying to make nonsense conversions of mismatched -- units, such as converting litres to metres or feet. -- -- NOTE C2: The various dimension-codes, so far, have been -- defined as letter codes, as follows: -- L=length, A=area, V=volume, FV=fluid volume, -- M=mass, F=force, T=temperature. -- Add other codes here, if likely to cause mismatches. -- -- NOTE P3: This template has only a partial list of units. -- Not all units are listed, here, because the goal of -- this template is to avoid the most-likely mismatches, -- not detect every conceivable mismatch of unit types. -- By using the [[80/20 rule]], excessive complexity is -- avoided by omitting rare cases which are likely to be -- spotted when checking results, rather than mapping -- hundreds of unit codes into dimension-codes. -- -- NOTE Z4: By acting as an [[accessor function]], using this -- template avoids passing a dimension-code parameter -- in hundreds of Convert subtemplates. In some cases, -- passing a parameter might be a better option, rather -- than invoke a template as an accessor. -- -- [ These comments are omitted during page-formatting by -- being within a <noinclude> section. As of October 2010, -- the MediaWiki parser puts HTML comments into the page -- of an article, unless comments are in noinclude tags. ] -- -------------------------------------------------------------- --HISTORY: --14Oct10 Created to get dimension code for some units. --14Oct10 Put NOTES comments to explain template coding. --14Oct10 Put HISTORY comments to log major changes. -- --> [[Category:Subtemplates of Template Convert]] </noinclude>

revision.comment: TDang moved page [[Strategy for Information Markets/Probability in Information Markets]] to [[Strategy for Information Markets/Background/Probability in Information Markets]]: Move to background
revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Strategy for Information Markets/Background/Probability in Information Markets]]

revision.comment: /* Elasticity */ more elasticity
revision.text:
When a firm makes decisions about output and prices, it is almost always the case that profit is maximized where marginal revenue equals marginal cost. The exact implications of this can vary depending on whether the firm is in a competitive market, and whether the firm is setting a single market price or engaging in more complicated pricing schemes.
Here we'll take a look at '''monopoly pricing''', meaning: # The firm has some amount of market power, and so faces a downward-sloping demand curve. # The firm is setting a single market price--any units they sell are sold at the same price.
==Market power== We'll talk about this kind of pricing as "monopoly pricing" because it's clearest in the case of a monopoly. A monopoly means the entire market is served by a single firm, and so the market demand curve is the same as that firm's demand curve. However, all that is required for this kind of analysis is that the ''firm's demand curve'' slopes downward, even if only slightly.
A downward-sloping demand curve means that the firm is not a [[Strategy_for_Information_Markets/Glossary#price taker|price-taker]]. So, when the firm raises its price, it will sell some amount less, and when it lowers its price it will sell some amount more. That's in contrast to a competitive market where a firm which raised its price above the market equilibrium would sell nothing at all, and if it lowers its price below market equilibrium, it will be losing money.
==Marginal revenue / marginal cost condition== {{Noframeright|1=[[File:Monopoly-surpluses.svg]]|2=Monopoly pricing, with the quantity Q* chosen to maximize profit where MR=MC, and the price P* chosen to result in that quantity}} In almost all cases, whether an industry is competitive or monopolistic, a firm can maximize its profit by selling the quantity for which marginal revenue (MR) equals marginal cost (MC). The intuition for that result is as follows:
Suppose that MR was greater than MC. That would mean the revenue from selling an additional unit is greater than the cost of making that additional unit. As long as this is the case, the firm will continue to produce more units, since each unit is profitable. Suppose instead that MR was less than MC. That would mean the cost of making an additional unit is greater than the revenue from selling it. If this is the case, the firm will cut back on its production, since it is taking a loss on those units. * when MR < MC, the firm is losing money, so it will produce less. * When MR > MC, the firm is making money, so they will want to produce more. * when MR = MC, this is an optimum level where the firm is making the most profit.
The MR=MC profit-maximizing condition applies to a firm in a competitive market, but in a trivial way. A Since a firm in a competitive market can't influence the price (p), MR = p regardless of how much output the firm produces. Therefore, a firm in a competitive market will maximize its profit by choosing a level of output where MC = p.
Since a monopoly has a downward sloping demand curve, they can influence the price. If they want to sell more, they have to lower the price they charge. That affects their revenue in two ways.
Suppose that the monopolist first is selling <math>Q_1</math> units at a price of <math>p_1</math>. Then they lower their price from <math>p_1</math> to <math>p_2</math>, and sell one more unit because of the lower price. The firm's revenue has ''increased'' by <math>p_2</math> because they sold the extra unit at that price. However, revenue has also ''decreased'' by <math>(p_1 - p_2)Q_1</math> because they are selling all the other units at the lower price as well. The second effect will be larger than the first effect, so MR will be decreasing as the quantity sold increases.
===Calculus approach=== The main goal of a firm is to maximize profit, which is given by: : <math>\pi(Q)=R(Q)-C(Q) = p(Q)Q - C(Q)</math>
To find the output which maximizes profit, we take the derivative of the profit function with respect to quantity: : <math>\frac{\delta\pi}{\delta Q} = \frac{\delta p}{\delta Q}Q + p - \frac{\delta C}{\delta Q}</math>
By setting the derivative equal to zero, we get: : <math>\frac{\delta p}{\delta Q}Q + p = \frac{\delta C}{\delta Q}</math>
There's a few things to notice about that condition. # The left-hand side is marginal revenue (MR), and the right-hand side is marginal cost (MC). # Marginal revenue comes in two parts. <math>\frac{\delta p}{\delta Q}</math> will be negative, since the quantity sold can only increase when the price decreases. So <math>\frac{\delta p}{\delta Q}Q</math> is the part of marginal revenue where revenue is lost on units which could be sold at a higher price. Then there's just <math>p</math>, which is the additional revenue from selling a unit which could not be sold at a higher price. Given the downward sloping demand curve marginal revenue is always less than the price.
{{TODO|This material really needs graphics, probably can find some on Wikipedia and/or Commons}}
==Elasticity== We will often use elasticity of demand to discuss the shape of a demand curve, and the elasticity will influence a monopolist's profit-maximizing behavior. Intuitively, if demand is [[Strategy_for_Information_Markets/Glossary#demand-elasticity|price inelastic]], then a firm could raise its price and quantity demanded would fall only slightly. This would be moving upward on the firm's demand curve. At the same time, moving upward on the demand curve will usually mean increasing elasticity, so the monopolist cannot keep raising its price this way forever.
If demand is price elastic, then a monopoly could lower its price a little and have the quantity demanded increase a lot. This would mean moving downward on the demand curve and also usually cause elasticity to decrease. Both of these forces push the monopolist toward a "middling" elasticity of demand, but which elasticity is the most profitable will depend on the firm's costs.
Demand elasticity (<math>\epsilon</math>) is the percentage change in quantity demanded for a percentage change in price: : <math>\epsilon = \frac{\%\Delta Q}{\%\Delta p}</math>
We'll primarily be using the calculus version which means the same thing, but is continuous: : <math>\epsilon = \frac{\delta Q}{\delta p}\frac{p}{Q}</math>
We can take the marginal revenue we found, <math>MR = \frac{\delta Q}{\delta P}Q + p</math>, and rewrite it in terms of elasticity: : <math>MR = \frac{\delta p}{\delta Q}Q + p = p\left(\frac{\delta p}{\delta Q}\frac{Q}{p} + \frac{p}{p}\right)</math> : <math>MR = p\left(\frac{\delta p}{\delta Q}\frac{Q}{p} + 1\right)</math> : <math>MR = p\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon} + 1\right)</math>
So far, that is just another way to write about the shape of the demand and marginal-revenue curves, and doesn't say how the firm should maximize profit. However, putting that together with the MR=MC condition: : <math>MR = MC</math> : <math>p\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon} + 1\right) = MC</math>
Remember that elasticity is usually negative, so we can see pretty quickly that if MC = 0, the most profitable elasticity is $\epsilon = -1$. This is called "unit elastic", and means demand is neither elastic nor inelastic. This is of particular interest for information goods, because in many cases, we will want to treat marginal cost as zero.
More generally, we can see that if $MC \geq 0$, then $\epsilon \leq -1$, so demand will never be inelastic when a firm is maximizing its profit. Intuitively, we can think that a monopolist might like inelastic demand because it means they can raise their price without losing many sales. However, because they like it and take advantage of it, they will keep raising their price and elasticity will rise until demand is at least unit elastic and possibly elastic.
* If demand is elastic, marginal revenue is positive (<math>\epsilon < -1</math>) * If demand is unit elastic, marginal revenue is zero (<math>\epsilon = -1</math>) * If demand is inelastic, marginal revenue is negative (<math>\epsilon > -1</math>)
{{BookCat}}

revision.text:
{{Documentation subpage}} <!-- PLEASE ADD CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS PAGE -->
'''[[Template:Convert/xx]]''' (for ranges using "xx") is invoked as the first template below {Convert}, for converting ranges such as {Convert|2|xx|4|ft|m}. It immediately invokes Convert/{4}, for the input unit {4}, passing the range of input numbers as "{1}|xx|{3}". Having obtained all 8 parameters, {1}|xx|{3}-{8}, it sets the precision "s" from either parameter {5}, {6} or {8} (depending on whichever is the numeric round-number); otherwise, the precision is set as: <nowiki>s=(0.5)+(0{{{s}}})</nowiki>. It passes {d} down as Dual/{d} to invoke subtemplate Convert/Dual/{d} which displays the dual-range (rather than the typical single amount). For any customization, such as disp=x, the parameters {6} and {7} are passed as {5} and {6} (or null if none). <includeonly> <!-- CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS HERE, THANKS --> [[Category:Subtemplates of Template Convert]] </includeonly>
